required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Myeloid Cells in Aortic Valve Stenosis
clinical_study.official_title: Myeloid Cell Reprogramming in Aortic Valve Stenosis

brief_summary.textblock: Investigators plan to characterize systemic inflammation and circulating immune cells in participants with moderate and severe calcific aortic valve disease and matched healthy controls.

detailed_description.textblock:
Calcific aortic valve disease (CAVD) is the most common type of valvular heart disease in the Western world. Due to the aging of the population, the impact of this disorder is expected to further increase in the next decades. The underlying pathophysiology remains incompletely defined and there are currently no effective medical treatments capable of altering its course, identifying a major unmet need in this growing population of patients.
Based on the similarities between CAVD and atherosclerosis in pathophysiology and shared risk factors, it is now hypothesized that activation of the innate immune system contributes to the development of CAVD. Therefore, the investigators will perform an observational study to assess the role of activation of the innate immune system in CAVD.

primary_outcome.measure: Inflammatory phenotype of circulating immune cells.
primary_outcome.description: The inflammatory phenotype of circulating immune cells will be measured by determining the cytokine production capacity after stimulation with relevant stimuli.

arm_group.description: Participants with severe CAVD and significant atherosclerosis
Participants with severe CAVD without significant atherosclerosis
Participants with moderate CAVD and significant atherosclerosis
Participants with moderate CAVD without significant atherosclerosis

Healthy controls without CAVD and without a history of atherosclerotic cardiovascular events, current typical complaints of angina pectoris or intermittent claudication and overt heart failure (NYHA class III/IV).

arm_group.arm_group_label: Controls with bicuspid aortic valve stenosis
arm_group.description: Controls with bicuspid aortic valve stenosis, without a history of atherosclerotic cardiovascular events, current typical complaints of angina pectoris or intermittent claudication.

intervention.description: Blood will be drawn after inclusion of the participants.
intervention.arm_group_label: Controls with bicuspid aortic valve stenosis

study_pop.textblock: Patients who present themselves or are already known at the department of cardiology or cardiothoracic surgery with the diagnosis of moderate or severe aortic valve stenosis as defined by transthoracic echocardiography according to the 2017 ESC/EACTS guidelines for the management of valvular heart disease.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age > 18 years
- Moderate to severe degenerative aortic valve stenosis as defined by transthoracic echocardiography according to the 2017 ESC/EACTS guidelines for the management of valvular heart disease.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Auto-inflammatory or auto-immune diseases
- Use of anti-inflammatory drugs
- Vaccination less than one month before inclusion
- Bone marrow transplantation in medical history
- Active hematological disease.
